paragraphs.text: CIA interrogations report: New Congress must tackle how to get intelligence right.
paragraphs.label: title

paragraphs.text: As I read news reports detailing the Senate Committee Report on the CIA interrogation program after the September 2001 terrorist attacks
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: I concluded there are several recurring problems to this latest effort to govern our national intelligence agencies
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: As an old man, I have had the opportunity to have first-hand exposure to how complex it is for Congress or even the White House to assert control over these vital intelligence activities
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: After there were revelations in the 60's that the CIA had engaged in a variety of activities that were highly questionable including efforts to kill Fidel Castro and others
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: the Carter administration reacted and went through the kind of political process that many are urging should be done today
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: In an attempt to purge the agency of its tendency to use nefarious individuals to carry out some of its covert projects, the CIA was directed to refuse to associate with any persons who could not meet the test of good character
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: One CIA officer told me how absurd that directive was
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: "We are trying to get people to betray their governments and to lie and cheat on our behalf. You cannot expect us to find those people in the front pew at the local churches."
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: Perhaps the directive was well-intentioned
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: but
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: it made no sense
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Richard Helms, the CIA head from 1966 to 1973, whom I knew well and admired greatly, told me of his personal problems when he was indicted by the Carter Justice Department for perjury
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: In testimony he gave to the Congress, Helms denied under oath his agency had been involved in the overthrow of the Allende government in Chile, an action ordered by President Nixon
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: Helms told me he was following instructions he had been given repeatedly by various Senators including such powerful men as Senators Richard Russell and Walter George to the effect
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: that if he were ever asked at an open hearing a question the answer to which "would put any of our people at risk" he should feel free to protect the secrets in whatever manner he wished
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: Of course Helms knew of many instances when he and others in the Agency had relied on that authority
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Helms was defended by the powerful Washington lawyer, Edward Bennett Williams
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: and
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: the case against Helms was quickly resolved
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: when Williams explained to the Justice Department his plan to have Helms take the stand and recite all the covert programs that had been protected by various forms of prevarications by intelligence officials
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: Of course
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: no such trial in public made any sense
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: and
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: the danger to ongoing intelligence activities of testimony such as Williams would have had Helms provide was so great the ill- advised indictment of Helms resulted only in a slap on the wrist
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Williams made a deal in which Helms pled guilty to a misdemeanor with no punishment
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: Later
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: President Ronald Reagan gave Helms the National Intelligence Medal as an obvious act of apology
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Perjury is not to be condoned and lying before the Congress is criminal conduct
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: But the intelligence world involves subtle issues
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: If
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: we want to have a major intelligence effort
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: there are clear costs to be accepted
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: One of them is that much of the necessary supervision by Congress has to be done with deft caution
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: It can hardly be conducted in open hearings
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Alan Dershowitz, the Harvard Law Professor and prominent civil libertarian, contends torture to save lives should be permitted as long as there are rigorous procedural safeguards
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: He points out the Israelis have used torture for years with apparent success
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: Getting information from unwilling prisoners cannot be done without some risks to civilized process
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: It can be a dirty game
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: I once visited Vice President Walter Mondale at his White House office
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: where he served under President Carter from 1977 to 1981
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: His desk was piled high with documents he said were mainly reports from the CIA
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: He volunteered his frustration at the then weaknesses at the CIA
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: He told me he had come to regret he had been such a vigorous supporter of the gutting of that agency that followed the suggestions of the so-called Church Committee on which Mondale had served as a Senator
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: His comment was an isolated one and I merely listened
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: But
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: the effects of the Church Committee recommendations were damaging to the CIA
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: and
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: the remedial work took years
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Every forty years we may have to endure periodic reports like those produced under Senators Church and Feinstein that represent well intentioned reviews of the intelligence community
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The suggested reforms speak of following our sense of justice and fairness and civility
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The problem is obvious
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Our enemies do not play fair
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: and
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: war is Hell
paragraphs.label: common-ground

paragraphs.text: Any reforms of the intelligence universe cannot easily be effected
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The idea of a transparent intelligence agency is an inherent contradiction
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Moreover how can Congress talk openly of reforms without damaging our intelligence efforts?
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: And politicians are among those least likely to be willing to accept the secrecy that is at the core of any well managed intelligence agency
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Can we imagine a Congress that can keep the secrets?
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The new flurry of attacks on the intelligence community -- harmful and unnecessary-- will not have any more lasting impact than did the indictment of Helms or the work of the Church Committee
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: But there should be some quiet and thoughtful debate within our Congress about how it can supervise these vital intelligence programs
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: After all
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: our national intelligence work is existential
paragraphs.label: assumption
